sentences: Maurice Georges Eugène Le Boucher (25 May 1882 – 9 September 1964), was a French organist, composer, and pedagogue.
Le Boucher was born in Isigny-sur-Mer.
In 1904, he entered the Conservatoire de Paris, where he was a student of Gabriel Fauré.
In 1907, Le Boucher won the prestigious Grand Prix de Rome.
Later, he became professor at the École Niedermeyer and organist at St. Germain-l'Auxerrois in Paris.
He wrote an Organ Symphony in E major, which was published in 1917 by Éditions Leduc, Paris.
He wrote a drama on Oscar Wilde la Duchesse de Padoue which was published by Salabert in 1931.
In 1920, he was appointed as director of the Montpellier Conservatory, a post he held for 22 years.
